column1: The Puerto Princesa Subterranean River National Park is a protected area of the Philippines.
The park is located in the Saint Paul Mountain Range on the western coast of the island of Palawan
column2: about 80 kilometres (50 mi) north of the city centre of Puerto Princesa
column3: and contains the Puerto Princesa Subterranean River. It has been managed by the City Government of Puerto Princesa since 1992.

column1: It was listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1999
column2: and voted as a New7Wonders of Nature in 2012. It also became a Ramsar Wetland Site in 2012.

column1: The Puerto Princesa Subterranean River National Park is a protected area of the Philippines located about 80 kilometres (50 mi) north of the city centre of Puerto Princesa
column2: Palawan. The river is also called 'Puerto  Princesa Underground River'. The national park is located in the Saint Paul Mountain Range on the western coast of the island. It is bordered by St. Paul Bay to the north and the Babuyan River to the east. The City Government of Puerto Princesa has managed the National Park since 1992. The entrance to the subterranean river is a short hike or boat ride from the town Sabang.
a group of environmentalists and geologists discovered that the underground river has a second floor
column3: which means that there are small waterfalls inside the cave. They also found a cave dome measuring 300 m (980 ft) above the underground river

column9: as well as marine creatures and more. Deeper areas of the underground river are almost impossible to explore due to oxygen deprivation.On November 11
column11: Puerto Princesa Underground River was provisionally chosen as one of the New7Wonders of Nature. This selection was officially confirmed on January 28

column1: The park has a limestone karst mountain landscape. St. Pauls Underground River Cave is more than 24 kilometres (15 mi) long and contains an 8.2-kilometre-long (5.1 mi) underground section of the Cabayugan River. The river winds through the cave before flowing directly into the West Philippine Sea and is navigable by boat up to 4.3 kilometres (2.7 mi) from the sea. The cave includes major formations of stalactites and stalagmites
column4: 180 ft) Italian's Chamber with approximate 2.5 million square meters volume. It is one of the largest cave rooms in the world. The lower portion of the river up to six kilometres (3.7 mi) from the sea
column5: is subject to tidal influences. Until the 2007 discovery of an underground river in Mexico's Yucatán Peninsula
column6: the Puerto Princesa Subterranean River was reputed to be the world's longest underground river.

column1: The area also represents a habitat for biodiversity conservation. The site contains a full mountain-to-the-sea ecosystem and has some of the most important forests in Asia. It was inscribed by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site on December 4
The park has a range of forest formations representing eight of the thirteen forest types found in tropical Asia
column9: and mangrove forest. Researchers have identified more than 800 plant species from 300 genera and 100 families. These include at least 295 trees dominated by the dipterocarp species. In the lowland forest
column10: large trees including the dao (Dracontomelon dao)
column14: and apitong (Dipterocarpus gracilis) are common. Beach forest species include bitaog (Calophyllum inophyllum)
column16: and Erynthia orientalis. Other plant species include almaciga (Agathis philippinensis)

column1: Birds comprise the largest group of vertebrates found in the park. Of the 252 bird species known to occur in Palawan
column2: a total of 165 species of birds were recorded in the park. This represents 67% of the total birds and all of the 15 endemic bird species of Palawan. Notable species seen in the park are the blue-naped parrot (Tanygnathus lucionensis)

column1: There are also some 30 mammal species that have been recorded. Most often observed in the forest canopy and along the shoreline feeding during low tide is the long-tailed macaque (Macaca fascicularis)
column2: the only primate found in the area. Other mammal species in the park are the Palawan bearded pig (Sus ahoenobarbus)
column4: Palawan stink badger (Mydaus marchei) and the Palawan porcupine (Hystrix pumila).

column1: 19 species of reptiles have been identified
column2: eight of which are endemic. Common species in the area include large predators like the common reticulated python (Python reticulates
column3: the monitor lizard (Varanus salvator) and the green crested lizard (Bronchocoela cristatella). Amphibian fauna include ten species. The Philippine woodland frog (Rana acanthi) is the most dominant and frequently encountered. One species
column5: endemic to Palawan was also observed in the area.

column2: two species of swiftlet and whip spider (Stygophrynus sp.) are found in the cave
column3: and the sea cow (Dugong dugon) and the hawksbill sea turtle (Chelonia mydas) feed in the coastal area of the park.

column1: Puerto Princesa Underground River was entered as the Philippine entry – and topped the first round of voting – in the New7Wonders of Nature competition. On July 29
column3: after the second round of voting
column4: it was declared 1 of 28 finalists. Mayor Edward S. Hagedorn extended his gratitude to all those who supported and voted for the PPUR. On November 11
column5: 2011 it was provisionally chosen as one of the New7Wonders
column13: Malacañang expressed elation on Saturday over the official inclusion of the Puerto Princesa Underground River (PPUR) in the world’s New Seven Wonders of Nature. "Confirmation that the Puerto Princesa Underground River is one of the New Seven Wonders of Nature is welcome news indeed. Throughout the competition
column14: Filipinos from all walks of life have given time
column17:
Presidential Spokesperson Edwin Lacierda said.Department of Tourism spokesman and Assistant Secretary Benito Bengzon Jr. said the underground estuary made it into the world’s New Seven Wonders of Nature after the validation process conducted by the New7Wonders Foundation last year. The voting was criticized, especially the Philippine voting. Nothing in the New7Wonders voting procedure prohibited repetitive voting, making the results subject to government and tourism industry campaigns to vote often for local sites with the financial incentive of increased tourism. Philippine President Benigno Simeon Aquino III, in his speech during the official proclamation launch of the Puerto Princesa Underground River as one of the 28 finalists, urged the country's 80 million cellphone subscribers to vote PPUR via text.On 30 June 2019, Puerto Princesa underground river was celebrated with a Google Doodle.
